Evidence Statements: • The student can draw a material before it is heated or cooled (e.g., show ice as a solid before heating).
• The student can illustrate what happens to the material after it is heated or cooled (e.g., show ice turning into water when heated).
• The student can demonstrate through a drawing how the material changes back when cooled or heated again (e.g., represent water turning back into ice when cooled).
• The student can depict the concept that some changes are reversible by showing both steps where the material changes and returns (e.g., water to ice and ice to water).
• The student can illustrate an example of a change that is not reversible, such as cooking an egg, to understand the difference in change types.
